name: Atomoxetine (Strattera)
summary: A selective norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor (NRI) approved for the treatment of attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) in children and adults.
description: Atomoxetine is a non-stimulant medication for ADHD that selectively inhibits the norepinephrine transporter, increasing norepinephrine levels in the prefrontal cortex. Unlike stimulant medications, it is not a controlled substance and has a lower risk of misuse. It may take several weeks to achieve full therapeutic benefit. It is often preferred in patients with comorbid anxiety, tic disorders, or a history of substance misuse.

monitoring_required: Liver function tests if hepatic symptoms occur

sections.text: Selectively inhibits the presynaptic norepinephrine transporter, increasing extracellular norepinephrine in the prefrontal cortex, which is associated with improved attention and impulse control.

adult.titrate: Increase to 80 mg/day after at least 3 days; may increase to 100 mg/day after 2–4 weeks if needed

sections.pediatric: Start at 0.5 mg/kg/day; increase to ~1.2 mg/kg/day; max 1.4 mg/kg/day or 100 mg/day, whichever is less

items: Capsules: 10 mg, 18 mg, 25 mg, 40 mg, 60 mg, 80 mg, 100 mg

sections.text: Some improvement may be seen within 1–2 weeks; full benefit may take 4–6 weeks.

sections.black_box: Increased risk of suicidal ideation in children and adolescents with ADHD.
other: Monitor blood pressure and heart rate regularly
Use caution in patients with cardiovascular disease
May cause severe liver injury in rare cases

items: Weight and growth in pediatric patients
Liver function if symptoms suggest injury

sections.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks; limited human data
sections.lactation: Unknown if excreted in breast milk; use caution
sections.pediatrics: Approved for ADHD in children ≥6 years
sections.geriatrics: Limited data; monitor cardiovascular parameters closely

sections.text: No withdrawal syndrome expected; tapering generally not required.

items: Preferred in patients with high risk of stimulant misuse.
May be beneficial for ADHD with comorbid anxiety disorders.
Slower onset of benefit compared to stimulants.
